overall_score_comment: Like a fortune cookie written by someone who just discovered anxiety — profound-ish, but we've all read this one before.
the_roast:
Benson Boone has given us the musical equivalent of bubble wrap: mildly satisfying to pop, but ultimately just air and plastic. The whole song is basically one long 'please don't jinx it' superstition set to piano chords. 'For a while there, it was rough / But lately, I've been doin' better / Than the last four cold Decembers I recall' — buddy, that's just called growing up. Congratulations on being slightly less miserable than you were during four consecutive holiday seasons. Someone get this man a participation trophy.

The chorus is essentially Benson standing in the middle of a field screaming 'DON'T TAKE MY STUFF!' at the sky like a toddler who just discovered object permanence. 'I want you, I need you, oh God / Don't take / These beautiful things that I've got' repeats so many times that by the end, even God is probably like, 'Dude, I heard you the first seven times.' It's less of a prayer and more of a contractual negotiation with the universe. The man found a girl his parents love and immediately started catastrophizing like he's in a Greek tragedy. Sir, this is a Wendy's.

And can we talk about 'there's no man as terrified as the man who stands to lose you'? That's beautiful in theory, but also... therapy exists. The whole song is just 'I'm happy but what if I'm not happy later?' stretched into three minutes. It's like watching someone win the lottery and immediately start planning their bankruptcy. 'I found my mind, I'm feelin' sane' — great, now maybe use that mind to practice some gratitude without the constant doomsday footnotes. This song is what happens when intrusive thoughts get a record deal.

hidden_meanings: Clearly, this song is a metaphor for Benson's relationship with his Spotify algorithm — he's finally made it big, but he's terrified the streaming gods will banish him back to four sad Decembers of zero monthly listeners. The 'girl his parents love' represents commercial success that checks all the boxes, and the constant begging 'please stay' is aimed directly at his spot on the Top 40 charts.
final_verdict: This song is the musical equivalent of knocking on wood after saying something nice — superstitious, endearing, but ultimately exhausting. Benson, my guy, try enjoying your beautiful things for five minutes before writing the breakup song.
title: Beautiful Things
